messages.subject: Re: [Unschooling-dotcom] educational vs. junk
messages.msgSnippet: Oh, Ok. Some may see it, as I did, that you re labeling some of life as work and marking it as more valuable than the stuff you limit. It s true that I used
messages.messageBody:
Oh, Ok. Some may see it, as I did, that you're labeling some of life as
"work" and marking it as more valuable than the stuff you limit. It's true
that I used labels you didn't use.

:-) Diane

Bridget E Coffman wrote:

> Diane,
> I'm sure you think that is how this group works but . . .
>
> I was told that I am not unschooling because I expect a certain amount of
> work from my kids each week. I did not say that I think other aspects of
> life are junk. I did not say I disallow all TV. I did say I have to
> limit it because I have a sone who is addicted. That is not an
> educational decision, it is a life decision.
>
> But I was still told, this is probably not the list for me.
>
> Bridget

messages.subject: Re: [Unschooling-dotcom] educational vs. junk
messages.msgSnippet: Diane, I m sure you think that is how this group works but . . . I was told that I am not unschooling because I expect a certain amount of work from my kids
messages.messageBody:
Diane,
I'm sure you think that is how this group works but . . .

I was told that I am not unschooling because I expect a certain amount of
work from my kids each week. I did not say that I think other aspects of
life are junk. I did not say I disallow all TV. I did say I have to
limit it because I have a sone who is addicted. That is not an
educational decision, it is a life decision.

But I was still told, this is probably not the list for me.

Bridget

I sent my Soul through the Invisible,

messages.subject: [Unschooling-dotcom] educational vs. junk
messages.msgSnippet: Hi, Luanne! This list is for unschooling support. In general you ll see this comment when someone says, I make my kids do this or that because it s
messages.messageBody:
Hi, Luanne!

This list is for unschooling support. In general you'll see this comment when
someone says, "I make my kids do this or that because it's educational." Most
unschoolers believe that, at root, this is not unschooling. Dividing life into
educational and junk categories is fundamentally not our philosophy.

If you post that you so divide the world and love it and so forth, yeah, you'll
probably hear that it's not unschooling. If you post that you have questions,
you'll probably get support, but if you only want support for declaring some
things junk, this is not the best place.

Hope this makes sense.

:-) Diane

Luanne Riley wrote:

> >Are you sure you mean to be on the unschooler list
>
> I'm relatively new to this list, but I have seen this question come up
> several times already. We use an eclectic approach, but strongly influenced
> by unschooling. I joined hoping to get ideas to more effectively apply the
> unschooling approach and gain confidence in it, but having this question pop
> up so much makes me wonder: Is this list only for those who are already
> wholeheartedly sold on unschooling or are you willing to help point those of
> us who are still learning in that direction?? I don't mean this to sound
> snide, I just don't want to waste my time on something that is going to end
> up being accusation and judgement.
>
